content.webTitle: Alex Salmond speech – first minister hits back over Scottish independence

fields.body:
2.10pm GMT

Here’s Nicholas Watt’s news story on the Salmond speech.

That’s it from me for the day. Thanks for all the comments.

1.22pm GMT

Alistair Darling, the leader of the no campaign, has put out this statement in response to Salmond’s speech:

Alex Salmond is pretending the last week never happened. It is now simple fact that Scotland cannot keep the pound if we leave the UK. Alex Salmond has a responsibility to tell us what will replace the pound. Will we set up a separate unproven currency or will we be rushing to join the euro?

Alex Salmond was arguing against about a problem of his own making - the problem of transaction costs for business due to changing currency. Avoiding extra costs to business and not placing jobs at risk are powerful reasons why we should vote to remain in the UK and keep the pound.

Leaving the UK and losing the pound will cost jobs, raise mortgage rates, increase credit card prices and make people’s weekly shop more expensive.

12.50pm GMT

He says there are no splits in the yes campaign over what will happen to the currency.

12.49pm GMT

The polls have been pretty stable, Alexander says, and come down for the union. But he is not complacent, he says.

12.49pm GMT

Salmond is going to try over the next 200 days to hide from Scots what will happen with the currency, Alexander claims. That “beggars belief”.

12.49pm GMT

Salmond is saying: “We want you to go for independence, but there is no map and no destination,” Alexander claims.

It’s very important that Scots have some facts, he says.

12.47pm GMT

He says the Lib Dems, Labour and Conservatives all agree that a currency union would not be good for Scots or for the remaining UK.

12.47pm GMT

Alexander is asked about Westminster politicians “bullying” Scots.

He denies there is any bullying. He is a Scot and has a vote, he says.

12.45pm GMT

But none of the alternatives to a currency union are very appetising, Alexander says.

12.45pm GMT

Danny Alexander, the Lib Dem chief secretary to the Treasury, is being interviewed on BBC News at the moment.

He says Salmond does not have clear answers to the questions raised by Osborne, Barroso, Carney and others. He should have stood up and said a currency union won’t happen - here’s my plan B, Alexander says.

12.43pm GMT

The Scottish government has issued a number of papers following Salmond’s speech, about the costs it says the rest of the UK would face if it did not go into a currency union with Scotland.

One paper claims the remaining UK would face costs of £500m.

Another challenges the no campaign’s claim that a currency union would limit Scotland’s economic independence.

On transaction costs to UK businesses, the Scottish government says:

Scottish government analysis illustrates that a separate Scottish currency has the potential to lead to transaction costs for rUK [the remaining UK] businesses of approximately £500m per year.

This cost would be incurred by industry and customers in rUK importing and exporting from an independent Scotland with an alternative currency.

This illustrative calculation uses estimates from research on costs and benefits of European Monetary Union to the value of trade between rUK and Scotland.

The second paper outlines 44 key economic levers in taxation, public spending, regulation and institutions, and representation an independent Scotland would gain.

These include power over corporation tax and income tax, regulatory levers in competition and consumer protection, control over spending on welfare and infrastructure, representation in the EU, international trade organisations and an independent foreign policy.

12.30pm GMT

Here’s some Twitter reaction to Salmond’s speech:

12.11pm GMT

If there was a new currency, people would want to know: “what’s it going to be worth tomorrow?” Darling says.

Salmond’s threat to default on Scotland’s share of the UK date is very irresponsible, Darling says.

And people know enough about Europe to know jobs depend on membership, he says.

With that the interview concludes.

12.10pm GMT

Alistair Darling, the former chancellor who is leading the no campaign, is being interviewed on BBC News now.

He says the trend among opinion polls is that sentiment has “barely moved” since the Scottish government published its white paper on independence.

But he is not complacent and has always said this would be closer than people think, he says.

That said, “the wheels are coming off the nationalist wagon”, he says.

People in the yes campaign are at odds over what to do about the currency, Darling says.

12.08pm GMT

Salmond says Scotland wants to raise its own money, govern its own spending, but share a currency - “why not?”

Asked about Barroso’s comments, Salmond points out that the EU is always expanding. His comments were “fantastic”. This was not an issue for the European commission, and anyway Barroso is retiring. The EU will respect a democratic vote from Scotland.

12.06pm GMT
